questions.question: At which OSI layer does a router primarily operate when making forwarding decisions?
questions.explanation: Routers read Layer 3 headers (IPv4/IPv6) to choose a next hop based on the routing table. — CCNA v1.1: 1.1a

questions.question: What is the main function of a router in a network?
options: Connecting devices within the same broadcast domain
questions.explanation: Routers interconnect separate IP networks and forward packets between them, creating Layer 3 boundaries. — 1.1a

questions.question: A router receives a packet for 192.168.10.5. The table has routes 192.168.10.0/24, 192.168.0.0/16, and 0.0.0.0/0. Which rule selects the outgoing interface?
questions.explanation: Routers choose the most specific route (greatest prefix length). /24 beats /16 and the default route. — 3.2 (ties to 1.1a)

questions.question: Which statement about broadcast domains is true when a router is placed between two switches?
options: The router merges both broadcast domains into one
The router blocks all unicast traffic
Each side of the router is a separate broadcast domain
Broadcasts can pass through if TTL is high
questions.explanation: Routers do not forward Layer 2 broadcasts; each router interface defines a new broadcast domain. — 1.1a

questions.question: Which entries are automatically installed in a router’s routing table without configuration?
questions.explanation: Directly connected networks appear when interfaces are up and have Layer 3 addresses. — 3.1 (foundation for 1.1a)

questions.question: Two equal-cost OSPF routes exist to 10.10.10.0/24 through different next hops. What will a router typically do by default?
options: Prefer the route with the higher metric
Perform per-destination load balancing across both
Install only the first route learned
questions.explanation: Cisco routers support ECMP and will load balance across equal-cost routes (per-destination by default). — 3.2/3.4 context

questions.question: Which item is compared first when multiple routes match a destination?
questions.explanation: Selection order: longest prefix match → then administrative distance (source trust) → then metric. — 3.2

questions.question: What is the purpose of a default gateway on a host?
options: To resolve MAC addresses for local devices
To provide DNS resolution to the Internet
To specify the switch port for trunking
To identify the router used to reach remote networks
questions.explanation: The default gateway is the router’s IP used when the destination is outside the local subnet. — 1.1a

questions.question: Which Cisco IOS command shows a router’s Layer 3 forwarding decisions and next hops?
questions.explanation: show ip route displays the routing table including sources, metrics, and next hops. — 3.1

questions.question: Which statement best describes static routes vs dynamic routes?
options: Static routes automatically adapt to failures; dynamic routes never do
Static routes are manually configured; dynamic routes are learned via protocols like OSPF
Both are learned from CDP updates
Static routes can only point to interfaces, not next-hop addresses
questions.explanation: Static routes are admin-defined; dynamic routes come from routing protocols and can reconverge after changes. — 3.3/3.4

questions.question: In IPv6, which address type is used by routers to forward packets across networks on the public Internet?
questions.explanation: Global unicast addresses are routable on the Internet and used for inter-network forwarding. — 1.1a (IPv6 context)

questions.question: Which Cisco feature speeds up packet forwarding by using a prebuilt FIB and adjacency table?
questions.explanation: CEF builds a Forwarding Information Base and adjacency table for high-speed Layer 3 forwarding. — 1.1a/3.2
